channel.title: Comments on: Setting up a Central Management Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Kevin Conan
item.dc:creator: Kevin Conan
item.content:encoded:
I updated the article with that security group (I had no idea it existed!).

I still like to list instances which will require SQL Authenication and not save the password. The reason is so that I still have a complete list of all my SQL Instances. I also wouldn’t recommend saving the password because it won’t be very security that way.

Thanks for the feedback!

item.title: By: SQLArcher
item.dc:creator: SQLArcher
item.content:encoded:
There are two built in roles provided for CMS, which are ServerGroupAdministratorRole as well as ServerGroupreaderRole which is a safer option to assign to developers (referencing your scenario).

Also, it is not really “possible” to use SQL authentication with CMS as it does not save credentials, whenever you connect to any server saved in CMS, your Windows Authenticated Credentials will be used.
